name: Ice (Solid H₂O)
description: Solid form of water. Crystalline structure created when liquid water freezes. Unique among common substances: less dense than its liquid form, which is why ice floats.

specificHeatSolid.description: Energy needed to raise 1 gram of ice by 1°C. Lower than liquid water, meaning ice requires less energy to warm up by the same amount.

heatOfFusion.description: Energy required to melt ice at its melting point (0°C). Significant amount of energy goes into breaking hydrogen bonds during melting.

density.description: Mass per unit volume at 0°C. Ice is approximately 8.3% less dense than liquid water, which is why ice floats. This is anomalous - most substances' solid forms sink in their liquid.

meltingPoint.description: Temperature at which solid ice converts to liquid water at standard atmospheric pressure.

meltingPointVariation.description: Ice melting point decreases with increased pressure. This is why ice skating works - pressure under the skate blade creates thin water layer.

crystalStructure.description: Most common form of ice at atmospheric pressure. Creates the characteristic six-fold symmetry of snowflakes. Over 20 different ice phases exist at extreme pressures.

molecularMass.description: Same as liquid water and steam - H₂O molecules arranged in crystalline lattice.

thermalConductivity.description: How well ice conducts heat. Much higher than liquid water (0.606 W/(m·K)), making it good for thermal applications but poor for insulation.

hardness.description: Ice is relatively soft compared to rock, but harder than most metals. Hardness varies with temperature and purity.

brittleness.description: Ice fractures easily, especially when cold. Becomes more plastic (deformable) as it approaches melting point.

transparency.description: Pure ice is transparent or translucent. Air bubbles trapped during freezing create white or cloudy appearance in normal ice.

coolingModel.description: Newton's Law of Cooling coefficient for solid ice. Lower than liquid water (0.0015) due to different surface properties and thermal conduction. Ice cools slightly faster than water per degree difference.

visualProperties.appearance: Solid crystalline structure. Can range from transparent (glacial ice) to white/opaque (air bubbles). Often appears blue-tinted in large masses.

sublimationTo.description: Direct conversion from solid to gas without passing through liquid phase. Common in frozen foods and dry ice like situations.

equilibriumWithWater.description: At 0°C (at standard pressure), ice and liquid water coexist in equilibrium

glacialIce.compression: Lower layers transformed to dense glacial ice by pressure

seasonalFrosting.thickness: 1 cm to several meters depending on location

permafrost.description: Permanently frozen ground in polar and high-altitude regions. Melting permafrost is major climate concern.

seaIce.extent: Vast seasonal variation in polar regions
seaIce.note: Different properties from freshwater ice due to salt content

snowFlakes.composition: Ice crystals that form in clouds
snowFlakes.structure: Six-fold symmetry from hexagonal ice crystal structure

anomalousExpansion.description: Water expands when it freezes (unusual!). Most liquids contract when freezing. This expansion exerts tremendous pressure and can crack pipes.

regelation.description: The property where ice melts under pressure and refreezes when pressure is released. Allows ice skating and is important in glacial flow.
regelation.example: A weighted wire can cut through ice - the ice melts under pressure below the wire and refreezes above it.

slidingFriction.description: Ice is slippery due to a quasi-liquid layer on the surface formed by friction and pressure, though this is more complex than previously thought.

metadata.educationalNotes: Ice's lower density than water is crucial for aquatic life - if ice sank, lakes and oceans would freeze from bottom up, killing fish. Instead, ice forms on top, insulating water below. The large heat of fusion (334 kJ/kg) explains why it takes significant energy to melt ice.
metadata.geologicalSignificance: Ice ages are defined by periods of extensive glaciation. Current ice sheets in Antarctica and Greenland contain climate records spanning hundreds of thousands of years in trapped air bubbles.
